ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i learned about material balances, single and multi phase systems, and energy balances
How to approach engineering problems. Topics covered included Energy and Material Balances, Single-Phase, Multi-Phase Systems, Thermodynamics and some introduction of Fluids.
not a good introduction to chemical engineering

Apart from the different types of balances we learned in class and the way we apply them to systems, I gained a better understanding of what the chemical engineering major is and I am able to apply what I learned into future classes.
I have learned that I am interested in chemical engineering. I took this course to see if this major could be for me, and I believe, after completing this course, that it will be.
I learned how to think about engineering problems systematically, and use a rational approach to solving new types of problems.
I learned the basics of chemical engineering analysis: mass balances, energy balances, and thermodynamics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: organized, clear lectures, helpful professor, helpful office hours
weaknesses: time-consuming problem sets

Strengths: Professor van Tassel is amazing, always very willing to stay back to help answer questions or concerns. He is also very accommodating and has flexible office hours. The psets weren't too long and very doable, if you needed any help, there was plentiful office hours. Weaknesses: None at all.

weakness: the homework was UNNECESSARILY and outrageously long, often because you had to look up random constants. facts, or equations (and had to figure out that this info must be looked up and is not expected to be known), not because the problem itself was difficult/time consuming to answer
I really enjoyed the course because it was based on the book so I always felt able to go back to each chapter if I ever had questions which is not possible for every class.

Honestly, I thought it was a really well taught course. The only potential weakness I could think of was that office hours with the professor were on Mondays, which was not ideal for me mostly because I had not started the problem sets by Monday. However, I feel this is more of a personal problem than a critique of the course.

The strengths of this course were that it was a good introduction to engineering concepts and we got a lot of individual attention because the class size was very small. The weaknesses of this course were that the lectures were really long and somewhat boring so it was hard to stay engaged for the full duration. Also each practice problem took a really long time so we didnt get to see as many examples during class. It was at times frustrating when homework and test problems didnt seem like anything we had seen in class.
I think the material that we learned was taught well, but most of the class time was used for going over example problems, and it feels like the pacing of the class was on the slower side.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: if you're certain you want to do cheme, it's a requirement. if you're not certain, maybe take an elective that caters to your personal interests first. this class was introductory and sometimes boring.
Yeah definitely take it if you're considering chemE and want to learn a bit more about the major.
no

I would really recommend it to others interested in engineering even if it is not chemical. I believe the class teaches things that are not always viewed as chemical engineering though they fall into the field, so taking this class would help have a better understanding of all of the engineering branches
Yes, I thought it was a really good introduction class to chemical engineering. I would recommend to another student looking for this experience.
If they had to take this course, yes.
